spanishExample: Tiene el pelo muy largo y las orejas muy grandes.
englishTranslation: She has very long hair and very big ears.

spanishExample: Él duerme hasta tarde y por eso eso fue hecho antes.
englishTranslation: He sleeps until late and that’s why that was done before.
vocabIncluded: advanced: use of Ser to create the passive voice, e.g. “fue hecho”
duerme: sleeps, he/she/it sleeps (Dormir, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Cuándo nos casamos? Si nos amamos, podemos casarnos pronto.
englishTranslation: When are we getting married? If we love each other, we can get married soon.
vocabIncluded: amamos: love, we love (Amar, present, 1st person plural)
casamos: marry, we marry (Casar, present, 1st person plural)
casarnos: to get married (Casar infinitive) + nos
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
cuándo: adverb meaning "when?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: Se me está ocurriendo una idea para hacer algo juntos, ya que dormiste hasta las once.
englishTranslation: I’m coming up with an idea to do something together, since you slept until eleven.
vocabIncluded: dormiste: slept, you slept (Dormir, preterite, 2nd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: Te amaba y fui muy feliz en ese momento.
englishTranslation: I loved you and I was very happy at that time.
vocabIncluded: amaba: loved, I loved (Amar, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Qué tienes en la frente y en el pelo?
englishTranslation: What do you have on your forehead and in your hair?

spanishExample: Siempre dormimos hasta tarde, pero ellos ayer durmieron muchas horas.
englishTranslation: We always sleep until late, but yesterday they slept many hours.
vocabIncluded: dormimos: sleep, we sleep (Dormir, present, 1st person plural)
durmieron: slept, they slept  (Dormir, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Se me ocurrió que no me amabas antes.
englishTranslation: It occurred to me that you didn’t love me before.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
amabas: loved, you loved  (Amar, imperfect, 2nd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
ocurrió: occurred, he/she/it occurred (Ocurrir, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tuvo un ataque al corazón, pero ya está bien.
englishTranslation: He had a heart attack, but he’s fine now.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: ¿Por qué no quieres que duerma con el cabello así?
englishTranslation: Why don’t you want me to sleep with my hair like that?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
duerma: sleep, I sleep (Dormir, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Van a casarse porque se han amado y todavía se aman.
englishTranslation: They are getting married because they have loved each other and still love each other.
vocabIncluded: aman: love, they love (Amar, present, 3rd person plural)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
casarse: to get married (Casar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Amo la medicina; quiero hacer algo así cuando sea mayor.
englishTranslation: I love medicine; I want to do something like this when I’m older.
vocabIncluded: amo: love, I love (Amar, present, 1st person)
así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"

spanishExample: He dormido pocas horas y mi cerebro no está muy bien.
englishTranslation: I’ve slept few hours and my brain is not very well.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Cuando me case, va a saber que lo voy a amar siempre.
englishTranslation: When I get married, he’s going to know that I’m always going to love him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
case: marry, I marry (Casar, subjunctive, 1st person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: El cerebro es muy importante y los oídos también.
englishTranslation: The brain is very important and the ears also.

spanishExample: Tiene una voz hermosa y quieren que me case con él.
englishTranslation: He has a gorgeous voice and they want me to marry him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
case: marry, I marry (Casar, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Te casaste con el médico justo cuando tenías problemas con tu pierna.
englishTranslation: You married the medic right when you were having problems with your leg.
vocabIncluded: casaste: married, you married (Casar, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Tengo dolor en la nariz y en la oreja y el enfermero lo sabe.
englishTranslation: I have pain in my nose and my ear and the nurse(m) knows it.

spanishExample: La comida está muy buena hoy y también es buena para tu salud.
englishTranslation: The food is very good today and it’s also good for your health.

spanishExample: Tienes una voz y oído geniales.
englishTranslation: You have a great voice and ear.

spanishExample: Dormimos hasta las diez, pero no siempre duermo tantas horas.
englishTranslation: We slept until ten, but I don’t always sleep for so many hours.
vocabIncluded: dormimos: slept, we slept (Dormir, preterite, 1st person plural)
duermo: sleep, I sleep (Dormir, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Queremos que duermas porque estás enfermo.
englishTranslation: We want you to sleep because you’re sick.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
duermas: sleep, you sleep (Dormir, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Por mi enfermedad y mi ataque al corazón, dormí mucho.
englishTranslation: Because of my illness and my heart attack, I slept a lot.
vocabIncluded: dormí: slept, I slept (Dormir, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Sé que me amas y que se te ocurrirá una buena idea.
englishTranslation: I know that you love me and that you’ll come up with a good idea.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
amas: love, you love (Amar, present, 2nd person)
ocurrirá: will occur, he/she/it will occur (Ocurrir, future, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Fue feliz por un tiempo, pero después estuvo enfermo.
englishTranslation: He was happy for a while, but later he got sick.

spanishExample: La amaba y nunca supo de su enfermedad.
englishTranslation: He loved her and never found out about her illness.
vocabIncluded: amaba: loved, he/she/it loved (Amar, imperfect, 3rd person)
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
supe: "knew / found out", "he/she/it knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se casó ayer, pero la fiesta es hoy en su casa.
englishTranslation: She got married yesterday, but the party is today at her house.
vocabIncluded: casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
casó: married, he/she/it married (Casar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Cuándo te casas? Nosotros nos casamos el año pasado.
englishTranslation: When are you getting married? We got married last year.
vocabIncluded: casamos: married, we married (Casar, preterite, 1st person plural)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
casas: marry, you marry (Casar, present, 2nd person)
cuándo: adverb meaning "when?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¡No duermas! Sabes que el enfermero va a venir.
englishTranslation: Don’t sleep! You know the nurse(m) is going to come.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Me ama con toda su alma; creo que quiero casarme pronto.
englishTranslation: He loves me with all his soul; I think I want to get married soon.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ama: loves, he/she/it loves (Amar, present, 3rd person)
casarme: to get married (Casar infinitive) + me
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Tiene problemas con la nariz y la frente y por eso durmió mucho.
englishTranslation: He has problems with his nose and his forehead and that’s why he slept a lot.
vocabIncluded: durmió: slept, he/she/it slept (Dormir, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Me preguntaste cuándo iba a casarme. Me caso mañana.
englishTranslation: You asked me when I was going to get married. I’m getting married tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: casarme: to get married (Casar infinitive) + me
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
caso: marry, I marry (Casar, present, 1st person)
cuándo: adverb meaning "when?" in a question or implied question
iba: "was going", "I was going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
preguntaste: asked, you asked (Preguntar, preterite, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No se le ha ocurrido un buen proyecto desde que se casaron hace dos meses.
englishTranslation: He hasn’t come up with a good project since they got married two months ago.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
casaron: married, they married (Casar, preterite, 3rd person plural)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Quiero que duerma muchas horas porque va a casarse mañana.
englishTranslation: I want her to sleep many hours because she’s going to get married tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
casarse: to get married (Casar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
duerma: sleep, he/she/it sleep (Dormir, subjunctive, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Se casa hoy por la noche y por eso está durmiendo.
englishTranslation: He’s getting married today during the night and that’s why he’s sleeping.
vocabIncluded: casa: marries, he/she/it marries (Casar, present, 3rd person)
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married

spanishExample: La boda es en ese lugar y por eso están muy serios.
englishTranslation: The wedding is at that place and that’s why they are very serious.

spanishExample: Se va a casar y no va a poder dormir mucho.
englishTranslation: He’s getting married and he’s not going to be able to sleep much.
vocabIncluded: casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ama la medicina con toda su alma.
englishTranslation: She loves medicine with all her soul.
vocabIncluded: ama: loves, he/she/it loves (Amar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se le tiene que ocurrir un plan para hacerlo.
englishTranslation: He has to come up with a plan to do it.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Vamos a casarnos y no se me ocurre nada mejor.
englishTranslation: We’re getting married and I can’t think of anything better.
vocabIncluded: casarnos: to get married (Casar infinitive) + nos
casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
ocurre: occurs, he/she/it occurs (Ocurrir, present, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No tiene buena salud y tiene problemas en el brazo.
englishTranslation: He doesn’t have good health and has problems in his arm.

spanishExample: Se ha casado con el médico y yo me casé con su amigo.
englishTranslation: She has gotten married to the medic and I got married to his friend.
vocabIncluded: casarse: any use of casar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to get married
casé: married, I married (Casar, preterite, 1st person)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Duermes sobre tu brazo izquierdo y por eso tienes problemas.
englishTranslation: You sleep on your left arm and that’s why you have problems.
vocabIncluded: duermes: sleep, you sleep (Dormir, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Esos libros fueron encontrados por esas personas.
englishTranslation: Those books were found by those people.
vocabIncluded: advanced: use of Ser to create the passive voice, e.g. “fue hecho”
